awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Ergativity in an Endangered Language
awd_abstract_narration:
Languages have vastly different ways of marking grammatical relations like subject and object, including differences in word order, marking on nouns and verbs, and employing different sentence structures altogether. The goal of this project is to investigate how grammatical relations can differ across languages and change over time, with a particular focus on an endangered language. By recording sentences, stories, and conversations with speakers, this project will document and analyze an unusual system of grammatical marking, which is undergoing rapid change due to contact with other languages. The resulting language documentation will be useful not only to linguists, but also to community members interested in maintaining the language.

The language being investigated shows an ergative alignment, where transitive subjects are treated differently from intransitive subjects and transitive objects; unlike many ergative languages, however, this pattern is only apparent in the formation of relative clauses, not from word order or marking on nouns and verbs. This pattern was previously thought to be impossible and presents some challenges for recent work in theoretical syntax. This research will explore the properties of this unusual pattern and its implications for our understanding of clause structure more broadly, including how clause structure is affected by language contact. To address this question, the study will be based on interviews with a broad sample of speakers, whose language use may differ according to age, education, and place of residence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During this project, I documented and analyzed the Nukuoro language, an endangered Polynesian language of Micronesia, in collaboration with Nukuoro community members. I conducted linguistic interviews with 5 speakers of Nukuoro to create a lasting record of the language, which is stored in an open-access archive at the University of California, Berkeley. For the first year of the project, these interviews were held entirely over Zoom, as the Micronesian borders were closed due to the Covid-19 pandemic. In June 2023, I was able to return to Micronesia with two junior researchers, where we conducted in-person interviews, recorded traditional Nukuoro narratives, held workshops focused on traditional skills like weaving and carving, and disseminated our research findings to community members.

In terms of intellectual merit, the elicitation interviews I conducted revealed new insights about Nukuoro grammar, which bear on wider theories of language and sentence structure. My dissertation provides the first detailed description of the Nukuoro language, which enhances our understanding of the Polynesian language family as well as endangered languages globally. This description focuses on the structure of basic Nukuoro sentences, as well as relative clauses and questions. The central chapters of my dissertation provide a description and analysis of a phenomenon called ergativity, a pattern found across the world's languages where subjects of transitive sentences are treated differently from other nouns. Ergative systems are known to vary widely from language to language; Nukuoro has some properties that are unusual for ergative languages, providing a clearer picture of what ergativity can look like in different instances. Related to ergativity, I describe and analyze a pattern in Nukuoro where certain questions and relative clauses cannot be formed. I drew on insights from a seemingly unrelated area, verbal agreement patterns, to develop a theory that unites question formation, verbal agreement, and information structure.

This project has several broader impacts for the Nukuoro community and the field of language documentation and revitalization. Nukuoro is spoken less frequently as younger generations migrate away from Nukuoro Atoll; as such, a primary goal of this project was to create resources to support language maintenance for the Nukuoro diaspora. As mentioned previously, all recordings made over the course of this project are available in a free, open-access web archive, which ensures that Nukuoro speakers all over the globe have access to documentation of their language and culture in perpetuity. My collaborators and I also created a user-friendly website to access recordings and published resources, and developed several bilingual Nukuoro-English storybook to bolster reading comprehension. Finally, this project demonstrates the value of community-driven language research projects: Nukuoro speakers led the direction of the project from the beginning, resulting in richer cultural documentation, creation of accessible language-learning resources, and a focus on community feedback at all stages of development.
